}}'''''The Lord of the Rings: The Treason of Isengard''''' was a third-person action-adventure video game under development by [[Surreal Software]] for PlayStation 2 and Windows, and [[The Whole Experience]] for Xbox. It was the sequel of ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (video game)
[[The Lord of the Rings (disambiguation): The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring]]'' and like its predecessor was based on the books. A separate edition was developed for GameBoy Advance by [[Pocket Studios]].<ref name="Gamespot-an">{{webcite

{{disambig-more: Black Label Games announces new The Lord of the Rings game

column4: accessed=27 august 2014}}</ref> It was to be released by [[Vivendi Universal]] in late 2003 but was cancelled in September 2003 due to failing the standards Vivendi had set for their games.<ref name="Gamespot-interview">{{webcite

{{disambig-more: [[File:The Lord of the Rings- The Treason of Isengard - Treebeard.jpg
The storyline of Treason of Isengard is based on [[The Lord of the Rings
The Lord of the Rings: books]], covering the second volume [[The Two Towers]], and continues where [[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (video game)
[[The Lord of the Rings (disambiguation): its' prequel]] ended. The storyline would feature [[Aragorn]], [[Legolas]] and [[Gimli]] pursuing the [[Uruk-hai]] and entering [[Fangorn Forest
column6: Sam]] and [[Gollum]], [[Shelob's Lair]], the  [[Battle of the Hornburg
column7: Battle of Helm's Deep]] and the [[Battle of Isengard]].<ref name="Trailer">{{webcite
column10: articlename=The Lord of the Rings: The Treason of Isengard Trailer 1

{{disambig-more: The player was able to take control of several characters. Whilst progressing the player would gain experience and could upgrade their characters. Other features included large battle sequences,<ref name="Gamespot-an"/> playing as an [[Ents
The Lord of the Rings: Ent]], online gameplay and downloadable content.<ref>{{webcite

{{disambig-more: The Lord of the Rings: The Treason of Isengard
The game would include several playable characters. Due to the game's cancellation it is unknown which charactars would be playable. This list only includes confirmed characters:
[[File:The Lord of the Rings- The Treason of Isengard - Witch-King Concept Art.jpg
column5:
Scheduled for release in Q4 2003, Treason of Isengard was dropped from the release schedule when it was determined that the game was not shaping up as strongly as anticipated and would likely not satisfy the expectations of Tolkien fans.

Vivendi Universal Games remains committed to developing and releasing quality games based on the literary works of J.R.R. Tolkien, and we look forward to the release of The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings: War of the Ring this November, as well as Middle-Earth Online next year.

{{disambig-more: Treason of Isengard was cancelled in september 2003. In an interview with [[wikipedia:Gamespot
The Lord of the Rings: Gamespot]], Andrew Shiozaki, senior brand manager of Vivendi, explained that Vivendi had reviewed their complete line-up of [[Middle-earth]] video games, which besides Treason of Isengard included ''[[The Hobbit (2003 video game)
[[The Lord of the Rings (disambiguation): The Hobbit]]'', the [[The Lord of the Rings: War of the Ring
column4: ''War of the Ring'' strategy game]] and the MMORPG ''[[Middle-earth Online]]'' (which eventually was released as ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'' by [[Turbine]]). It was deemed that Treason of Isengard failed the standards that Vivendi had set for their Middle-earth video games and was therefore cancelled. Instead, they focussed on the remaining three video games.<ref name="Gamespot-interview"/>

{{disambig-more: Brad Spear, who previously composed music for the ''Fellowship of the Ring'' video game, composed original music for Treason of Isengard, as well as tracks based on themes composed by [[Chance Thomas]] for ''[[Middle-earth Online]]'' (which later became known as ''The Lord of the Rings Online''). Several music demo's were available for download on the - now offline - site <nowiki>www.lotr.com</nowiki><!-- , this included tracks known as "The Elves Return to the Sea" and "The Battle of Pelennor Fields".<ref> http://www.assemblergames.com/forums/showthread.php?50475-LOTR-Treason-of-Isengard-(Unreleased)-Demo </ref> (needs checking)-->. Some tracks were reused for ''The Lord of the Rings: War of the Ring'' and ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]''.<ref>{{webcite
column4: articlename=Chance Thomas' Lord of the Rings Themes Surpass 1 Million Downloads
